The days grow colder, the nights grow longer. That means /co/ Christmas cheer is coming to town. Grab some cocoa, turn on the Christmas music, get comfy, and hang out with some /co/mrades as we share stories and get into the holiday spirit.

As previous years, share your Amazon wishlist and some random Anon may purchase a holiday gift for you. Be sure to gift another Anon in return so we can spread the cheer far and wide.

Please check the Pastebin to learn how to get your wishlist code, add a shipping address, the benefits of using AmazonSmile, and all other information.

Last year we had 132 gifted anons, some more than once.

Ungifted lists: pastebin.com/SmVHgMRE
All lists: pastebin.com/ZCXuvfE5

To get your wishlist code, open your wishlist on Amazon, then copy the 11 digit number from the link. It will look like this: amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/###########
We just need the ###########

Missing Address: When viewing your list, click the "…" in the upper right hand corner. From there click "Manage List" which will give you a few options including “Shipping Address”. While you’re here please check “Third party shipping agreement”. That will allow anons to buy you stuff that isn’t sold by amazon.

>>134464991
Gadget tells her who he is, what he does, and promises to take her to work tomorrow, since he's told she'd probably appreciate it. Indeed she does. She meets the Slicksteins, one about twice her age, the other four times her age. They're a pair of quirky inventors and tell her that the older Slickstein is the reason her uncle gadget has his gadgets in the first place. The accident that killed her mother mortally wounded Gadget, and they were able to save his life by transferring his mind into this body. We'll circle back to this later, but in the meantime they introduce Brain to the two.The Slicksteins thought having an augmented partner for Gadget would be ideal, but Gadget is reticent to work with a different partner. Corporal Capeman is already his partner, but the Slicksteins exchange sideways glances, tell Gadget "about that" and explain he needs to debrief with the chief. Still Brain comes along because he and Penny have bonded.

Penny is also given a "computer book". It was her mother's way of recording intelligence in the field. They've got better ways now and this had been wiped but they felt like perhaps she'd like the one gadget her mother always had on her.

Instead of Chief Jacques Nozzaire, he meets with a short, balding man, Quimby. Quimby explains that Nozzaire got a promotion and poached by the Military. He'd read all of Gadget's missives from the field and was exceptionally impressed with his competence. The intelligence Gadget had gathered on MAD would surely go a long way to bringing them down. Gadget agrees and thinks he and Capeman would be able to do so. Quimby then informs him that Capeman has actually been sent on a new assignment. It was thought their effors could be focused in separate directions.

So spoiler alert, Capeman is a mole in the intelligence agency Gadget works for. He deactivated Gadget and falsified reports in his name for a decade. Here he's a very british spy, kind of Austin Powers but not as charming.

last_replies.com:
Final review is that I thought it was okay. the script is tight and everything seems to happen for a reason but the supporting cast overshadows the main character and I almost wish the movie somehow was about them and not the kid. They are fun and competent at what they do but you need to stop and give the MC something to do and feels forced, every bit of drama and conflict that he is involved feels somewhat forced and he just "being there" and having little to contribute with very little outside knowing music and in the end all he needs to play is 3 fucking notes? Weak sauce.

The movie drags a lot towards the beginning and middle, but the third act is actually really good and brought me back to it proving how tight the script. The animation also picks up and we do have a few cool action scenes towards the end but I can't help but picture this movie in a 90's classic style of animation like iron giant or Titan and you can see how much better it would have been. The jokes feel like classic disney somehow, like the Seth joke and the sort of villain he is and the pairing with the wannabe pharaoh, really felt like I was watching an mid 2000's Disney movie and you can tell. Lot's of darker jokes on this one too and most were pretty great. Overall is a 6;5, had potential to be better but is not really terrible. Really doesn't feel like an movie but more an episode from a series that somehow got stretched to be a entire movie but is not really bad. I can see people basically nitpicking and saying is terrible because it has the Disney brand associated and really is on the cheap side visually even if not deserving but is serviceable, I would show to my kids if I had any and wasn't a loser reviewing a children's movie at 3 AM in the middle of the week.

Best girl is definitely Joan but since I study occult stuff she would probably try to kill me, second best choice is the cat.

sub: Evaluation of Tom and Sarah's relationship
com:
Tom and Sarah's relationship is an interesting thing in the show however I believe it wasn't really thoroughly explored even though it isnt really a drama series.
In the beginning Tom and Sarah seem fine but later on it's shown that Sarah wants Tom to be more dominate and Tom does not really do that causing frustration. This brings an interesting point, why did Sarah marry Tom in the first place? How come she hasnt seen that he isnt not a dominate man of her dreams.

What about their daughter? Jazmine doesnt seem to be effected at all from their fighting. It's just shown that she cries in the moment when Tom slapped Usher however nothing else really. She cares for her dad and i think her mom as well.

Is it possible for these two so somehow mend their relationship or should they just get a divorce?

Also just to throw this out there, I feel like the show makes Tom the sympathetic party whereas in the comics its a bit more balanced. (note I've only read until August 22, 2001 so i might be jumping to conclusions)

What are your thoughts anons?

com: I literally cannot remember the name of this for the life of me, but I know it was published some time before 1990. I think it was a newspaper comic originally, because the comicbook I had it in was a distinct style of long-width short-high sofotcover that was popular in Australia for newspaper comic compilations like Footrot Flats, Swamp, Snake, and Garfield. It might have been a Flash Gordon story, perhaps? All I remember is that it revolved around these hideous spidery aliens kidnapping humans to transplant their brains into better bodies. I particularly remember it for the bleak tone (the heroes came to rescue their son and his wife, but the wife had already had her brain replaced, so the son shoots her then blows his own brain out) and the nudity. Also, there was this old, space wizard-type character who teleported the heroes, a husband and wife team, to and from the planet. Pic unrelated.
